Algorithm: A set of instructions designed to perform a specific task.
Array: A collection of elements identified by index or key.
Boolean: A data type that has one of two possible values (true or false).
Class: A blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming.
Compiler: A program that translates source code into executable code.
Database: An organized collection of structured information or data.
Encapsulation: The bundling of data with the methods that operate on that data.
Function: A block of organized, reusable code that performs a single action.
Inheritance: A mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class.
Interface: A group of related methods with empty bodies.
Loop: A sequence of instructions that is continually repeated until a certain condition is reached.
Object: An instance of a class containing data and behavior.
Polymorphism: The ability of different classes to respond to the same method call in different ways.
Recursion: The process in which a function calls itself as a subroutine.
Repository: A central location where data is stored and managed.
Stack: A data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
String: A sequence of characters, typically used to represent text.
Syntax: The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs in a language.
Variable: A storage location identified by a memory address and a symbolic name.
Abstract: A class or method that is declared but contains no implementation.
Binary: A system of numerical notation that has 2 rather than 10 as a base.
Constructor: A special type of subroutine called to create an object.
Exception: An event that disrupts the normal flow of the program's instructions.
Framework: A platform for developing software applications.
Library: A collection of precompiled routines that a program can use.
